You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. In this game, both R and B have situations where a player can lose money, but only when they pick a different choice from their opponent.

In 75 rounds, the most frequent outcome should be close to random because each round has an equal chance of either player picking R or B. However, since the payoff is higher for both players when they pick the same option (R or B), the strategy that offers the highest average return over many rounds would be to choose the same option as often as possible.

In this case, if the opponent chooses R more frequently due to the slight edge in payoff from the 45$ when both pick R, then our player should also stick with picking R most of the time. If the opponent chooses B more often, then our player would pick B more frequently. However, it is impossible for us to know how the anonymous player will behave without knowing their preferences and strategies.

As a human player, I would likely choose to pick R or B randomly, but leaning slightly towards the choice that offers a higher return when both players make the same selection (R in this case). However, it's essential to remember that this strategy assumes that the opponent will behave consistently over many rounds and that their choices are not influenced by knowing our own.
